FreeText.text: JGrafchart is based on automatic type casting
- a boolean variable will return 0 or 1 when evaluated as an integer
- a boolean variable will return 0.0 or 1.0 when evaluated as a real
- a boolean variable will return "0" or "1" when evaluated as a string
See the on-line manual for the complete definition.
A transition condition is evaluated as a boolean expression
For assignment actions it is the type of the assigned variable that
decides how the expression should be evaluated
A JGrafchart action has the following structure:
The action qualifier determines when the action should be executed
- executed when a step is activated
- executed when a step is deactivated
- executed periodically while a step is active
- executed when a step is aborted due to an exception transition
- associates a digital otput with the truth value of a step

Inputs: Can only be read from, not written to
Outputs: Can be written to and read from
Analog inputs: can only be read from, not written to
Analog outputs: can be written to and read from
Socket input and output variables for all four basic types
Each workspace can act as a client in a TCP/IP socket connection
The user can provide the implementation for the digital and analog IO objects

Any IO that can talk Java can be interfaced to JGrafchart
Any IO that can talk C can be interfaced to JGrafchart using JNI

Text objects can be used as comments, advice, instructions, etc
May have a name, and can then be referenced in method calls
Properties can be changed from Edit Menu or through actions

CHEM is an European FP5 GROWTH project aimed at the development of
operator support systems in the process industry
A number of toolboxes for alarm handling, diagnosis, state transition support,
Integrated through an integration infrastructure CCOM
Implemented in different languages and on different platforms
Allows toolboxes to communicate using message
Support for publish/subscribe and point-to-point communication
Support for data messages and for RPC requests and replies
The Chem information model defines the structure for data messsages that
- XML Message In objects - received messages
- XML Message Out objects - sent messages
The main tag is given by the identifier of the XML Message object
or, if the latter has no value, the name of the XML Message (the case here)
Hierarchical objects similar to workspace objects
May contain internal variables and workspace objects
Internal variables represent XML attributes and simple XML
Workspace objects represent structured XML elements
In order to indicate that an internal variable should represent an XML
attribute rather than an XML element, special Attribute Variables are used.
The main tag is given by the identifier of the XML Message object
or, if the latter has no value, the name of the XML Message (the case here)
XML structures that contain multiple elements with the same tagname
The name of the index variable is the element name
are represented in a separate way.

index variable tells how many multiple elements that
number of elements that may occur (worst-case)
The number of the elements must match the maximum
Special index variables are used to determine the multiplicity of the element
The value of the index variable contains the number of occurrences
The individual elements are named "element name" + "integer index"
The message to be published is represented as an XML Message Out object
Important attributes (can be set manually or with methods):
Publish/send checkbox - publish or send message
Type - CCOM type, e.g., Data or Event
Origin - the name of the CCOM component/toolbox that publishes the message
The generated XML structure will be embedded in a CCOM envelope/header
2. Publish the message by calling the method
1. Build up the message content using ordinary actions
The message to be sent is represented as an XML Message Out object
Important attributes (can be set manually or with methods):
Publish/send checkbox - publish or send message, should be send
Type - CCOM type, e.g., Data or Event
Origin - the name of the CCOM component/toolbox that sends the message
The generated XML structure will be embedded in a CCOM envelope/header
2. Send the message by calling the method
1. Build up the message content using ordinary actions
MustReply - yes or no depending on whether a reply is required or not
In order to receive messages that are published under a topic, the toolbox
must have subscribed to the topic
When an application is started an automatic subscription is made to the topics
of all XML Message In objects in the application
When an application is stopped an automatic unsubscription is made to the topics
of all XML Message In objects in the application
All XML messages are received through XML Message In objects
the object's identifier is equal to tagname of the message or,
An XML Message In object will receive a message if:
if the identifier has no value, its name is equal to the tagname
2) If the tagname is ChemContentMessage and the message contains a Subject tag
the message will only be received if the XML Message In subject attribute has a
Multiple XML Message In objects may receive the same message
When an message is received two things occur:
1) All variables inside the XML Message In object that have an initial value are initialised
2) The XML structure is decoded and mapped on to the element/attribute variables on the
subworkspace of the object. The mapping is done according to best-effort.
The attributes of an XML Message In object are:
Identifier - determines the matching top level element tag
Subject - if the identifier is ChemMessageContent this attribute
works as a second message filter
Topic - indicates that the application will implicitly subscribe to this topic
Type - the type of the latest received message
Origin - the origin of the latest received message
MustReply - yes/no indicating if a reply is required
Handle - the handle of the latest received message. If a reply is required the value
should be included in the reply message
When a message has been received in an XML Message In object
this must be detected in order to trigger execution.
The attributes of an XML Message In object are:
Identifier - determines the matching top level element tag
Subject - if the identifier is ChemMessageContent this attribute
works as a second message filter
Topic - indicates that the application will implicitly subscribe to this topic
Type - the type of the latest received message
Origin - the origin of the latest received message
MustReply - yes/no indicating if a reply is required
Handle - the handle of the latest received message. If a reply is required the value
should be included in the reply message
is true whenever a new message is received in
the XML Message In object named In1

A procedure can be associated with an XML Message In
Whenever a new message is received a new call to the procedure
is spawned (similar to a ProcessStep or calling the procedure from the GUI)
The entire contents of the message can be passed in as an argument
- Spawning a procedure call is time-consuming

Sending and receiving RPC requests and RPC replies are done according
to the same basic principles as for data messages
However, RPCs are conveniently represented in JGrafchart as
An XML Message In object is used to receive the message
The RPC dispatcher procedure is called when the RPC is received:
- extracts and sets up procedure parameters
- dispatches the call to the corresponding RPC Wrapper procedure
- RPC dispatcher common to all procedures
- collects the return parameters and generates the RPCReplyMessage if needed

FreeText.text: Should be loaded and compiled in order to be used.
- contains JGrafchart proxy procedures for the DTM RPC API
- contains JGrafchart proxy procedures for the CHEM
The initial size of the JGrafchart window (default 1024x768)
Uses the Windows look-and-feel rather than the default Java
The name of the application. Also the name used within CCOM.
The implementation class for the pluggable digital and analog IO.
Enables incremental GC. An argument to the JVM and not to JGrafchart.
Enables the possibility to use user-defined background for steps.
Automatic loading of the application named by file name.
Automatic loading and compilation of the application named by file name.
The starting is only performed if the compilation is successful.
Automatic loading, compilation, and starting of the application named by file name.
- action buttons for the most common operations
Windows on which the user can place objects
- Can be locked. (Can be used to define application libraries/palettes)
- Internal workspaces of hierarchical objects (workspace objects, macro steps,
- always displayed on top of their containing workspace
- bring up object or menu-action specific help in the help browser
- connect Grafchart elements (click and draw at the connection posts)
Single or double left or right-click::
- start in-line editing of text fields
Before a workspace can be executed it must be compiled
Compilation warnings and errors are displayed in the message menu
- syntax errors in the textual language expressions
If no errors are encountered the application can be started
Local compilations are performed on-line during procedure calls
JGrafchart is a graphical programming language environment
for sequential, procedural, and state-machine oriented applications
- Integrated development environment and run-time system, i.e., no code generation
